rsbNotes.title: Lev 17–27
rsbNotes.text: 17:1–27:34 In these chapters, the Lord’s demands for holiness clearly reach into every aspect of Israel’s life. In a discussion on topics as diverse as sexual behavior and the Year of Jubilee, capital crimes and the tabernacle loaves, the Lord teaches that Israel must reflect His holiness in their behavior.

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19
rsbNotes.text: 19:1–37 The theme of holiness is elaborated as God instructs the people on principles of good neighborliness. The chapter illustrates what holiness meant in daily life. See Introduction: Characteristics and Themes (cf. Matt. 5:48; 1 Cor. 11:1; 1 Pet. 1:16).

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:2
rsbNotes.text: 19:2 See “God Is Light: Divine Holiness and Justice” at 11:44.

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:5
rsbNotes.text: 19:5 peace offerings. See note 3:1; cf. 7:16–18.

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:9–10
rsbNotes.text: 19:9, 10 See Ruth 2:2–23.

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:13
rsbNotes.text: 19:13 wages of a hired servant. See Deut. 24:14, 15.

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:17
rsbNotes.text: 19:17 reason frankly . . . because of him. A candid yet tactful reproof of the wrongdoer is better than storing up destructive hatred against that neighbor and so causing oneself to sin as well (Prov. 27:5; Matt. 18:15; Gal. 6:1).

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:18
rsbNotes.text: 19:18 love your neighbor. A “neighbor” was anyone with whom there was contact, whether Israelite (v. 17) or alien (v. 34; cf. Matt. 22:39, 40; Rom. 13:9).

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:19
rsbNotes.text: 19:19 Respecting boundaries and distinctions was an aspect of holiness.

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:21
rsbNotes.text: 19:21 guilt offering. See note 5:14–6:7.

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:24
rsbNotes.text: 19:24 Firstfruits, like firstborn livestock and children, were to be given to God (Ex. 22:29, 30; 23:19), for Israel was God’s firstborn and so was consecrated to Him (Ex. 4:22).

rsbNotes.title: Lev 19:28
rsbNotes.text: 19:28 Mutilation of the body created by God was incompatible with holiness, for the holy God is perfect life (Deut. 14:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: Lev 20
rsbNotes.text: 20:1–27 The instruction here repeats many of the same points of chs. 18; 19 (for parallel verses, consult the cross-references), but with the addition of prescribed penalties. The death penalty is indicated for many offenses, pointing to the horror with which God viewed them (cf. Rom. 1:18–32). In other cases divine penalties, such as cutting off (7:20 note), are mentioned; these cover situations where detection might be difficult (v. 18) or family solidarity might make the head of the family reluctant to punish (v. 17).

rsbNotes.title: Lev 20:6
rsbNotes.text: 20:6 See Deut. 18:10, 11; 1 Sam. 28:9.

rsbNotes.title: Lev 20:9
rsbNotes.text: 20:9 Jesus quoted this text in Mark 7:10.
